title: When will the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) next screen fewer than 1.3 million travelers per day for three consecutive days?
preds: Very very close back in January, but ultimately: "No."
Oops!  I misread the TSA data! @hrokr
with 8 days remaining in the second to last bucket - and current forecast exceeding 2 million - upping my prediction to this not occurring prior to 1 April

I do not think a new variant will change this fast enough to drop off nearly a million travelers from the average for three straight days.  HOWEVER, the outbreak of a world war could, maybe, and there's certainly a nonzero chance of that.
off chance of maybe exceeding the 3 million during spring break period - but
I can see a world wide ground stop in the event of a cyber attack on ATC's etc. elevating till we see what really happens in Ukraine.
We've passed the Omicron surge, they'll not see numbers as low as Dec/Jan until the next surge, well after March.

Wow. Can't believe how close it came. With 99% of forecasts betting on April for the past 7 months, 03FEB came within 39,534 of triggering the February answer. No one will EVER convince me this question wasn't determined by luck.
2/3/2022	1,339,533	
2/2/2022	1,192,973	
2/1/2022	1,200,580 1/26/2022	1,198,339	
1/25/2022	1,059,741	
1/24/2022	1,397,281
Only 8 days below mark in the last 30 days. As more states open up, travel should only increase specially around Spring break.

The volume of travelers in early February of 2019 and 2020 were relatively low compared to November and early December, and there was almost a three day period of under 1.3 million travelers at the beginning of the month already. So it seems possible that this could happen. Weather could also be a factor.
If it hasn't slowed down due to Omicron, it likely will not slow down again.

It was close over the last 3 days.  If this big snowstorm didn’t leave 3 consecutive days below 1.3m then it’ll take a lot for it to happen!   
But it’s only early Feb.  Plenty of time for more bad weather.
After the near miss this week, I'll up the odds for next week few.
I was expecting that the thousands of cancelled flights would put it under 1.3 million today, but somehow it was still able to be just above that.

Below 1.3m on 1st with three more days of winter storm drifting across different parts of the US affecting lots or different airports.  This might disrupt travel enough to reach the three day requirement
I think it should happen fast, otherwise we'll climb out of the Omicron-dip already.
Yesterday's count of 1.5M holds the pattern to just two consecutive days below 1.3M. I'm reserving some probability in bin 4 in case next week continues the downtrend.
The last two days have been below the threshold...
Near term risk of occurrence given the much lower that expected traffic yesterday signalling a possible trigger this week. But, If Thursday is over 1.3, bin 3 will be eliminated.
See if we can get this one…

22/23/24 January 2022 is the best bet for now for bin 3. ORD (O'Hare International Airport, Chicago) is top of the list on the "Misery Map", with 41 cancellations today and almost half of all flights delayed.
https://de.flightaware.com/miserymap/ Being a central hub for the US from the Midwest into all other regions, ORD's weather situation is going to impact other major air traffic destinations from LAX, DEN, DAL, ATL to CLT, DC and NYC for a few more days. Being a low traffic day, Sunday 23 January '22 is fairly certainly going to come out between 1.1mn and 1.2mn passengers, which makes 22/23 January a two-day-stretch with below 1.3mn passengers already.
The question really is whether the Great Lakes region have such a bad weather that previous cancellations cannot be made good for on Monday (24 January '22) and whether icy conditions will even affect the New England region to such an extent (BOS, DC, NYC,...) that 800 to 1,000 additional inbound flights with 200k to 300k passengers need to be cancelled for Monday.

Upping the forecast again for this weekend. 
18 Jan 1.301m (yes above threshold, but very close)
19 Jan 1.2m
20 Jan lots of flights cancelled - good chance of being below 1.3m https://uk.flightaware.com/live/cancelled/
21 Jan bad weather continues across parts of south.  Balanced by it being Friday so weekend flights will kick up passenger numbers.  I don’t think Friday will be less than 1.3m, but It could happen, so going to risk it for a biscuit.

International flight cancellations due to 5G rollout technical mismanagement.
Especially risky at impaired visibility conditions.
2 days in a row less than 1.3m this week.  Putting a high forecast for rest of Jan just in case weather does affect flights that much for 3 days, then will revert to longer horizon.

Blizzard conditions from Georgia to Vermont likely for 17 January '22.
No way this question is going to survive beyond 19 Jan.
5% for the pandemic keeps on throwing surprises, plus ditto re: the weather
15 inches of snow ahead for the New England states, for the five days beginning 14 January 2022.

https://www.airlines.org/dataset/impact-of-covid19-data-updates/
Slide 10 and 11 show how air travel rates compare before Covid.  We can clearly see the Atlantic travel has steadily increased since Nov 21 changes to travel rules and is slowly tricking upwards.  This will make it harder to drop below 1.3m as it’s a big market. Leaving some likelihood in for before April in case the current Omicron wave has an impact or as @se_meyer suggests, winter weather and having to isolate coincide and cause an unexpected drop.
Severe winter weather disruptions plus staff shortage : flight cancellations.
Everyone has pretty much had it with covid restrictions, so they're doing what they want, including travel.

Even if a variant would spread rapidly, I do not think the American people would greatly decrease traveling (3 consecutive days) unless federal government implemented travel restrictions again. However, it was recently announced that travel will reopen to Canada and Mexico for those who are vaccinated which trends towards a regulated travel system instead of a restricted one for future outbreaks.
Watching the TSA throughout data at a daily frequency.  It looks like it bottomed in mid-September, and it is starting to inflect higher on the margin.

https://www.reuters.com/business/aerospace-defense/air-france-klm-eyes-capital-options-us-bookings-surge-2021-09-29/
Airlines are meditating on the need for new equipment.  One supposes they will expect these new aircraft to have people in them, and in the meantime one supposes that their existing inventory will be heavily used.  Should be safe at 100% on this one, but the world is full of surprises--mostly unpleasant ones.

International travel will be back on now the US has reopened borders to the EU.  But how much? Note that in recent weeks there have been several occurrences of 2 days below 1.5m and some single days below 1.3m.  Will need to keep a look out to see if any more impact happens as infections continue to rise in the US.

Based on personal travel experience, shifting my forecast again.  Here are some observations:
- While business travel was obviously light, it was clearly occurring.  There appeared to be a conference last week in Portland, Maine and our hotel was solidly booked mid-week.  Plenty of conference badges around.
- Weekend travel was significant.  The hotel breakfast bar on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday was overflowing.  
- Masks are optional outside of airports.  Noses are fairly common in airports though.
- Leisure travel appears to be primarily dominated by 50+ and those without kids. 
- I am receiving at least one "Wanna Get Away" e-mails per week with one-way prices of less than $100 across the entire US.  Airline are clearly lowering prices to fill seats. My prior is that early to mid-September would be the low point for fall / winter travel due to continued Covid-19 cases, negative headlines about air travel, and return to office / school.  This appears to be showing up in the data.  The next 15-days (and especially the Tuesday - Thursday combinations) will be key to watch.  Business travel is likely to increase into Q4'2021 due to increasing vaccination rates and desire to keep business relationships.
1.2M passengers yesterday, only 52.9% of the traffic compared to the corresponding Tuesday in 2019.  Very limited time left for the first bin but there is a chance.

There is the odd 1.3m day at the moment, but 3 days in the row is quite a drop.  Even with the rising cases in the Us the flight numbers haven’t dropped that far, so seems unrealistic for such a drop off to happen unless there is some big crisis other than COVID.

Increasing before 1 October from 1% to 5% due to material reluctance for business travel to engage.  WSJ article explained in well: https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-19-resurgence-clouds-business-travel-rebound-11630920600?mod=hp_lead_pos1 The risk is highest on any given week will be from Tuesday to Thursday, which would be primarily prime business travel days.  After this surge of Covid-19 has primarily run its course [note: my base case is that the surge has run its course by 1 November in the US], between herd immunity and vaccinations, unless there is a variant that further reduces the effectiveness of current vaccines AND US consumers change their behavior, it is very unlikely we will dip below this threshold.
It's late for me, was the 31st Aug a result of some kind of corporate or government mandate?

Just saw that the TSA trend has been decreasing since 29JUL21 by about 12,851 passengers per day which is almost the exact same decreasing trend seen from 29JUL19-29AUG19. The trend could persist due to COVID fears which would breach the threshold on 30SEP21, so I'm estimating a non-zero likelhood the context will resolve in one of the earlier brackets. If I apply the 2019 daily trend using the 28AUG21 passenger counts though, there would be 10 sub-1.3MM days between 14MAR22-15APR22 but there would never be 3 consecutive days in a row.
The number of people who don’t want the vaccine will restrain all levels of the economy
No  deaths associated with the newest COVID wave, so I expect U.S. domestic travel will remain open.
Their's a lull in there somewhere.

Seeing enough commentary around pilot shortages that gives me pause that there could be a dip in passenger traffic in our future.  COVID and travel frustration for passengers and crew may take a toll.  Daily passenger trendline actually down after a rough week of high cancelations.
The spread of the delta variant is increasing the likelihood of a near-term material decrease in flight.
I don't think the travel passports would help to much, if there is breakthrough covid cases, if those numbers increase, then they most likely will resort back to screening tests.

There is too much pent-up demand to travel and governments are loathing to put restrictions back in place.  If the Lambda variant spreads and the vaccine cannot be quickly changed, it may be possible that over the winter travel may be shut down, but I view that as unlikely
It's more likely that Airlines will require proof of vaccination or a test before boarding, rather than shut down again.

This forecast is based on:
1-The Gradual Increase  in flights and screen checks for will go up till 13th of Sep 2021 (where TSA urges travelers to be aware of airport checkpoint changes at least up to mids of Sep 2021.
https://www.wvgazettemail.com/news/kanawha_valley/tsa-urges-travelers-to-be-aware-of-airport-checkpoint-changes/article_89206c86-c109-5f9f-bbc8-24a56d5f499e.html 2-But taking in to consideration the delta variant spark , a new lock down can be forced to take place inorder to lower travelling screening& life activities.
https://www.businessinsider.com/delta-variant-covid-economy-consumer-behavior-lockdown-bank-of-america-2021-7
I don't see this as a likely event - we won't see another lock-down like situation, even though delta will surge.  People will get another round of boosters and the unvaxxed will do what they do.
It won't get that low again. People are not going to put up with lockdowns again
If they don't manage by the end of summer, then I don't think the hysteria will die down anytime soon.

I don't see travel dipping to that level again, even with the delta variant out. I think the general mood nationally is that either you get vaccinated or subject yourself to the possibility of a terrible reaction to covid. Though people know the vaccine isn't perfect, it generally guards against death by covid. Given this, people aren't going to hunker down again unless a truly terrible strain with an entirely new set of symptoms and killing ability appears.
Around school schedules and flue season

If there's a time when this occurs, it will be before October 1 after the college migration and before fall break travel. After that point, there will be a steady rise in travel barring another huge variant that impacts the nation. That impact should it occur, would likely happen after April 2022.

When considering this question, I believe there are two important dimensions: (1) Timing of Travel Mix: Business vs. Leisure Travel, and (2) The Race: mRNA Vaccination Rates vs Covid-19 Variant mutations.   For (1) Timing of Travel Mix:  Business travel appears with a gradual build over the next 12-months.  Currently, only 40% of companies have resumed domestic travel with only another 24% expected to resume domestic travel over the next three months [https://www.gbta.org/Portals/0/21st_Poll_Results_07-19-21.pdf?ver=2021-07-16-152603-997]. Importantly, resuming domestic travel and volume of domestic travel are two separate concepts.   As a result, business related travel in September and October is likely to remain subdued simply because domestic travel from corporates remains constrained.  At the same time, it is likely to slowly increase as the US reaches herd immunity.  Based on simple forecasting, domestic business travel demand is low and slowly increasing. Leisure travel is the other important dynamic.  This is harder to capture with data (so far).  After the summer travel season with pent up vacation demand, will this continue at these levels in the fall?  I honestly do not know.  However, how would I plan a vacation during this period?  Utilize vacation days for long weekends so travel will be solid from Friday through Monday.  What about Tuesday through Thursday thought? For (2) The Race (mRNA Vaccination Rates vs. Covid-19 Variants):  In the near-term the delta variant appears to be impacting well-known vacation locations, such as Florida.  However, as students go back to school and offices expect employees to return, there is a likelihood of increased cases associated with the delta variant.   I would hope that increased cases would spur those who have chosen to not get vaccinated to get vaccinated.  In my opinion, this risk will be largest before October 1st. So below are the two questions that I think really matter for this question:
(1) When will the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) next screen fewer than 1.3 million travelers per day for three consecutive days from Tuesday to Thursday?  
(2) Will a new Covid-19 variant that is worse than Delta emerge and get around the vaccination?   I think both are a low probability; however, there is an elevated chance before 1 October 2021 due to the delta variant, low business travel, and a reduction in leisure travel mid-week.

Vaccination + 4th wave : herd immunity...
Likelihood of a variant that is unchecked by vaccines is low probability...
It would take a large covid wave before final vaccinations have occured for this to happen at this point.

While I don't believe that passenger volume will dip to that level for a 3-day period, I do leave some chance for the unexpected - weather, war, enough State Governors locking down their populations to impact the numbers as a whole.

With current infections on the rise and traveller numbers hovering around the 2m mark, I can’t see the reduction to 1.3m any day, let alone for 3 days in a row, unless something drastic happens.  But I struggle to see how the US would put the genie back in the bottle and go back into lockdown given that life has been continuing for many even when the case rates were high.

The ratio between the 2021 weekly average and the 2019 weekly average (I'm using weekly averages because there are significant variations that depend on day of week) has been growing from around 40% at the beginning of 2021 to around 80% in early July 2021, and has been stable around 80% since then. Modeling the projected values going forward at 80% of baseline (2019), and even at 70% doesn't result in any 3-day periods below 1.3M. I'm leaving 2% in Nov and 3% in Jan to account for historical lows due to seasonality, but I doubt they will happen.
Need to track over time the ratio between 2021 and  2019.
